docs.snippet: What's the most sensible way to make it easier and more likely for people to cast their ballots on the day America unites to go to the polls?
docs.abstract: What's the most sensible way to make it easier and more likely for people to cast their ballots on the day America unites to go to the polls?

docs.snippet: The mayor of a small Pennsylvania town is resigning after sparking outrage by posting images on his Facebook page comparing President Barack Obama and his family to apes and referencing a noose.

headline.print_headline: Pennsylvania Town's Mayor Quits After Racist Anti-Obama Posts
headline.main: Pennsylvania Town's Mayor Quits After Racist Anti-Obama Posts

docs.snippet: The town council on Monday voted to accept the resignation of the Republican mayor after an uproar over racist posts on his Facebook page, including two depicting apes with captions referring to Democratic President Barack Obama and his family.

headline.print_headline: White Mayor Who Acknowledged Racist Posts Allowed to Resign
headline.main: White Mayor Who Acknowledged Racist Posts Allowed to Resign

docs.snippet: Plunging print ad sales and an explosion of online outlets spreading inaccurate information threaten to diminish, and in some cases extinguish, the impact of traditional media companies.

headline.print_headline: Journalism’s Next Challenge: Overcoming the Threat of Fake News
headline.main: Media’s Next Challenge: Overcoming the Threat of Fake News

docs.abstract: Jim Rutenberg Mediator column laments fate of good journalism after presidential election ends; notes many credible news organizations are planning cutbacks, assuming current bump in readership and advertising will disappear at conclusion of politically contentious race; fears situation will leave Americans without counter to dubious news circulating on social media.

docs.snippet: Police on Friday released new details about the mysterious resignation in July of an Illinois lawmaker, outlining how he fell prey to an online extortion ring based in the Philippines.

headline.print_headline: Ex-Illinois Lawmaker Was Bilked by Philippine Extortion Ring: Police
headline.main: Ex-Illinois Lawmaker Was Bilked by Philippine Extortion Ring: Police

docs.snippet: A recall of 2.8 million washing machines in the United States exceeds the 1.9 million Galaxy Note smartphones recalled last month.

headline.print_headline: Samsung, Still Reeling From Galaxy Note Failure, Recalls Washing Machines
headline.main: Samsung, Stung by Galaxy Note Failure, Recalls Washing Machines

docs.snippet: The Times asked women around the world why they had kept or changed their surnames when they married. For many, the decision carried significant weight.

headline.print_headline: Readers Reflect on Changing Their Surnames for Marriage
headline.main: ‘I Didn’t Want to Lose My Identity’: 16,000 Readers Reflect on Their Surnames

docs.snippet: The police in Michigan wanted to take a rescue dog from its owner, saying he was a banned pit bull. Now the legal battle is over.

headline.main: Diggy the Dog’s Internet Fame Almost Cost Him His New Home

docs.snippet: Viktor F. Yanukovych, the former president of Ukraine, said that his “main mistake” was not declaring martial law, but that he did not want to cause a civil war.

headline.main: Ukraine’s Ex-Leader Regrets Not Breaking Up Protests That Led to His Fall

docs.snippet: German opinion on immigration is polarized, but stable, after the killing of 12 people at a Christmas market.
